revision.comment: Removing link(s) to "New york city": capitalisation; please re-add caplitalised. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Greg Skibiski | image = skibiski_greg_004.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|34|2008|6|22}}<ref name="NY Times 2008/06/22" /> | birth_place = | nationality = American | occupation = | known_for = founder of Sense Networks | networth = | spouse = | children = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Gregory Roman Skibiski''' (born 1973), is an [[American (word)|American]] [[entrepreneur]]. Skibiski is the [[Founder (company)|founder]]<ref>[http://www.sensenetworks.com/pr_06292009.php "Sense Networks Secures Series B Funding for Location Analytics, Led by Intel Capital"], ''Sense Networks corporate website, Media Center'', New York, 30 June 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-14.</ref><ref>[http://www.intel.com/capital/news/releases/090630.htm "Press Release: Sense Networks Secures Series B Funding for Location Analytics, Led by Intel Capital"], ''[[Intel Capital]]'', New York, 30 June 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-13.</ref> and former [[Chairman of the Board|Chairman]] & [[Ceo|CEO]] of [[Sense Networks]], a New York City based company focused on analyzing [[big data]] from [[mobile phone]]s and [[carrier network]]s.<ref name="NY Times 2008/06/22">Fitzgerald, Michael. [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/22/technology/22proto.html?_r=2&scp=1&sq=sense+networks&st=nyt&oref=slogin "Predicting Where You’ll Go and What You’ll Like"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', New York, 22 June 2008. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref><ref name="newsweek1">Sheridan, Barrett. [http://www.newsweek.com/2009/02/27/a-trillion-points-of-data.html "A Trillion Points of Data"], ''[[Newsweek]]'', New York, 28 Feb 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref><ref>Baker, Stephen. [http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/09_10/b4122042889229.htm "Mapping a New, Mobile Internet"], ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'', New York, 26 February 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref><ref>Markoff, John. [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/30/business/30privacy.html?scp=2&sq=Greg+Skibiski&st=nyt "You're Leaving a Digital Trail. What About Privacy?"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', New York, 29 November 2008. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref><ref>[http://www.sensenetworks.com/ Sense Networks, Inc. corporate website]. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref> Skibiski is named lead<ref>[http://appft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=/netahtml/PTO/search-bool.html&r=0&f=S&l=50&TERM1=skibiski&FIELD1=&co1=AND&TERM2=&FIELD2=&d=PG01 US Patent & Trademark Office]. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref> [[inventor]] on three [[patent application]]s for analyzing emerging [[sensor]] data streams from mobile phones, culminating in the Macrosense, Citysense [http://www.citysense.com/], and Cabsense [http://www.cabsense.com/] products.<ref>Silver, James. [http://www.wired.co.uk/wired-magazine/archive/2009/06/features/the-hidden-persuaders-mining-your-mobile-phone-log.aspx "The Hidden Persuaders"], ''[[Wired Magazine]]'', London, 22 June 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref>
Citysense was named by [[ReadWriteWeb]] (in The [[New York Times]]) as "Top 10 Internet of Things Products of 2009".<ref>Macmanus, Richard. [http://www.nytimes.com/external/readwriteweb/2009/12/08/08readwriteweb-top-10-internet-of-things-products-of-2009-74048.html "Top 10 Internet of Things Products of 2009"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', New York, 8 December 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-13.</ref>
==Life and career== The idea for Citysense started in 2006 when Skibiski approached [[Alex Pentland|Alex "Sandy" Pentland]] (Head of [[Human Dynamics]] Research at the [[MIT Media Lab]]) with the idea that large amounts of location data being collected by mobile phones and GPS devices could be useful to [[economists]].<ref>Junietz, Erika. [http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:hKKbZBAfYHYJ:www.sensenetworks.com/press/mit-tech-insider.pdf+skibiski+idea+created&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESheMj8iT2tzutepbEVsOwFl3_EAsOKF-hZSF2RwUWQzE12nAX8N7-iUegcn_ooA1VchAzO_42c7qaDJcXIsQ1qBTV8H-1JUKdHyI1tj68FgQ5A3dw5o5MIxiH7ldPMLHfIEUCVz&sig=AHIEtbT2N32A-ERj0s16J8Fx0LSD30FxZg "A Sense of Place"], ''MIT Technology Insider'', Boston, August 2008. Retrieved on 2010-05-14.</ref><ref>Davey, Justin. [http://venturebeat.com/2008/11/28/five-location-based-services-to-watch-in-2009/ "Five Location-Based Services to Watch in 2009"], ''VentureBeat'', San Francisco, 28 November 2008. Retrieved on 2010-05-14.</ref><ref>Stern, Allen. [http://www.centernetworks.com/sensenetworks-citysense-mobile "Sense Networks Answers the Question, 'Where's the Party At?'"], ''CenterNetworks'', San Francisco, 9 June 2008. Retrieved on 2010-05-14.</ref><ref name="oreilly1">Forrest, Brady. [http://radar.oreilly.com/archives/2008/06/citysense-reality-mining-iphone.html "Citysense: Lets You Know What Everyone's Doing"], ''[[O'Reilly]]'', San Francisco, 9 June 2008. Retrieved on 2010-05-14.</ref> Technology to do that analysis did not exist at the time.<ref name="technewsworld1">Raphael, JR. [http://www.technewsworld.com/story/63327.html?wlc=1273904379 "GPS Mapping Shows Where the Action Is"], ''TechNewsWorld'', San Francisco, 9 June 2008.</ref>
Skibiski's original theory was that analyzing large amounts of location data from mobile phones and vehicles would provide value to the financial services and retail industries, enabling "an entirely new business model for location-based services" based on monetizing macro trends in spending and sentiment.<ref>Levine, Barry. [http://www.newsfactor.com/news/Citysense-Monitors-Human-Traffic/story.xhtml?story_id=0210023DVF7R "Citysense Monitors Real-Time Human Traffic"], ''[[CIO Today]]'', 9 June 2009.</ref><ref name="poptech1">Stepanek, Marcia. [http://legacy.poptech.org/blog/index.php/archives/3985#more-3985 "New Deal on Data"], ''[[Pop!Tech]]'', San Francisco, 29 May 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-14.</ref> For retailers, information ranging from where else its customers shop to how far people travel to get to its stores. Like Web analysis tools, determining where customers were immediately prior to entering the business—a real-world "referring site" kind of concept.<ref name="technewsworld1"/>
It became apparent that trends in how far shoppers are willing to travel to get to a store like Macy's, Saks or Nordstrom could indicate monthly trends in that store's sales.<ref>Gupta, Ritesh. [http://news.thewherebusiness.com/content/using-location-analytics-mine-mobile-location-data-user-segmentation "Using location analytics to mine mobile location data for user segmentation"], ''[[The Where Business]]'', San Francisco, 1 July 2010.</ref> People who worked in the financial district would to go to work early when the market was booming, but later when it was down. Plotting San Francisco nightlife patterns on the same graph as the Dow showed that, just before the market peak in July 2008, urban partygoers hit the town at later-than-ever times.<ref>Markoff, John. [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/30/business/30privacy.html?scp=2&sq=Greg+Skibiski&st=nyt "You're Leaving a Digital Trail. What About Privacy?"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', New York, 29 November 2008.</ref><ref>[http://en.oreilly.com/where2009/public/schedule/detail/7263 Where 2.0 Conference, San Francisco, "Greg Skibiski's Keynote: Decoding the Urban DNA and Harnessing the Power of Social Intelligence". 20 May 2009. Video.]</ref> Beginning mid-2006 Skibiski's firm used location data to operate a trading portfolio.<ref>Sheridan, Barrett. [http://www.newsweek.com/2009/02/27/a-trillion-points-of-data.html "A Trillion Points of Data"], ''[[Newsweek]]'', New York, 28 Feb 2009.</ref>
Skibiski was pushed out by [[lead investor]] [[Intel Capital]]<ref>Baker, Stephen. [http://thenumerati.net/index.cfm?postID=489 "Data correlation: Used-car customers drop cell-phone service?"], ''[[The Numerati]]'', New York, 8 January 2010. Retrieved on 2010-05-14.</ref> in November 2009 shortly after closing the company's B round of financing, in the same week the company was named one of "The 25 Most Intriguing Startups in the World" by [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] <ref>Ante, Spencer. [http://images.businessweek.com/ss/09/11/1112_most_intriguing_companies/index.htm "The World's Most Intriguing Startups"], ''[[Bloomberg BusinessWeek]]'', New York, 12 November 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-12.</ref> and won the Emerging Communications Conference "Company to Watch" Award.<ref>[http://www.sensenetworks.com/pr_11022009.php "Sense Networks Wins the Emerging Communications Conference & Awards Inaugural "Company to Watch" Award"], ''[[Press Release]]'', New York, 2 November 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-16.</ref>
Originally from [[Northampton, Massachusetts]], Skibiski attended the [[Williston Northampton School]] from 1985 through 1991.<ref name="linkedin">[http://www.linkedin.com/in/gregskibiski Greg Skibiski], linkedin.com, Retrieved 2011-01-06.</ref> He received his bachelor's degree in [[Civil engineering|Civil Engineering]] from [[Bucknell University]] in 1996 and his [[Mba|MBA]] from [[HEC Paris]] in 2006.<ref>[http://www.hec.edu/News/HEC-Graduate-Greg-Skibiski-Indexes-the-Real-World/(offset)/40 "HEC Graduate, Greg Skibiski, Indexes the Real World"], ''[[HEC Paris]]'', Paris, 25 June 2008. Retrieved on 2010-05-13.</ref> Skibiski was also one of the first employees at BackWeb Technologies, a [[Tel aviv|Tel Aviv]] based internet infrastructure software company that had a successful NASDAQ IPO in 1999.<ref>[http://www.milkeninstitute.org/events/gcprogram.taf?EventID=GC09&SPID=3740&function=bio "The Mobile Web"], ''[[Milken Institute]]'', Los Angeles, 27 April 2009. Retrieved on 2010-05-13.</ref>
==Privacy and data ownership== Although there have been doubts as to its practicality, Skibiski has been an advocate for the [[New Deal on Data]], as created and evangelized by [[Alex Pentland|Alex "Sandy" Pentland]] from The MIT Media Lab.<ref name="newsweek1"/><ref name="oreilly1"/><ref>Diaz, Carly. [http://archive.picnicnetwork.org/page/66524/en "Interview with Greg Skibiski". Amsterdam, NL. 29 September 2009. Video.]</ref><ref>Bollier, David. [https://libshare.library.gatech.edu/clearspace/servlet/JiveServlet/download/3664-2-1836/Bollier-09_bigData.pdf;jsessionid=61F4AEA482CD3D1D51C473BF0150DB5D The Promise and Peril of Big Data (book)] Eighteenth Annual Aspen Institute Roundtable on Information Technology, Aspen, Colorado, 2010. ISBN 0-89843-516-1</ref> “The idea behind the New Deal on Data is based on Old [[English Common Law]] saying you have the right to possess something, use it and dispose of it. "So if you’re a company and you're keeping their location data, the end user should own it and have a say over whether it should be destroyed.”<ref name="poptech1"/>
The [[New Deal on Data]] also provides for the aggregate, [[Anonymity|anonymous]] use of location data for the [[public good]], such as predicting [[Tuberculosis]] outbreaks in Africa. “If you can find and identify an outbreak just one week earlier, you’re saving thousands of lives.”<ref>Tsai, Jessica. [http://www.vscconsulting.com/dev/clients/Articles/8169/DestinationCRM_1.1.10_PlaceCast.pdf "Here, There and Everywhere"], ''[[DestinationCRM]]'', San Francisco, January 2010. Retrieved on 2010-05-15.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Bollier, David. [http://www.aspeninstitute.org/sites/default/files/content/docs/pubs/InfoTech09.pdf The Promise and Peril of Big Data] Eighteenth Annual Aspen Institute Roundtable on Information Technology, Aspen, Colorado, 2010. ISBN 0-89843-516-1
* Paparella, Maureen & Simko, Eugene. [http://www.textbooks.com/BooksDescription.php?BKN=936645&SBC=DDJ&KEYWORD_K=isbn%201439038708&kenshu=68a5a891-410f-88a9-b398-00003e8f6298&tracking_id=5362806&utm_source=google&utm_medium=cpc&utm_term=isbn%201439038708&utm_campaign=ISBN%20-%20Group%205%20-%20Search&gclid=CLvC3ZTr0qECFShqswodfiTGIg "Current Topics in Technology"], 15 June 2009. Textbook. ISBN 1-4390-3870-8
* Nicolao, Hardmod Carlyle. [http://www.amazon.com/Greg-Skibiski-Hardmod-Carlyle-Nicolao/dp/613650412X "Greg Skibiski, Entrepreneur, Chairman, Sense Networks"], 8 August 2011. ISBN 613650412X{{Please check ISBN|reason=does not match hyphenation rules and is probably invalid}}
==External links== *[http://archive.picnicnetwork.org/page/66524/en "Interview with Greg Skibiski". Amsterdam, NL. Diaz, Carly. 29 September 2009. Video.] *[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/22/technology/22proto.html?_r=2&scp=1&sq=sense+networks&st=nyt&oref=slogin ''New York Times'': Predicting Where You'll Go and What You'll Like]
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}
